etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Cranmer (1489–1556), archbishop of Canterbury. From post-classical Latin adunation-, adunatio mystical union, (of people) meeting, gathering from adunat-, past participial stem of adunare to unite + classical Latin -iō

definitions: The combining of two or more things into a single entity; union, combination.

notes.text: Now only with reference to E.-J. Sieyès.
